data.title: [WIP] Use WSL PHP for validation
data.body:
Related to #22391 

WORK IN PROGRESS. DO NOT MERGE YET.

I am having an issue fetching the standard output from the spawned validator process. What I am doing is spawning a cmd.exe process, and that spawns a bash.exe process who in turn runs "php -l -n -f /path/to/file/to/validate.php". However, this callback is never called:

https://github.com/codeguy/vscode/blob/feature-wsl-php-validator/extensions/php/src/features/validationProvider.ts#L284-L287

I have not hooked up custom configuration settings yet. I am simply forcing VSCode to use WSL php for validation with these temporary lines:

https://github.com/codeguy/vscode/blob/feature-wsl-php-validator/extensions/php/src/features/validationProvider.ts#L252-L265

Do you have any thoughts why I am not getting any stdout?

I have seen this issue with WSL:

<del>https://github.com/cpdt/slinky/issues/11</del>

Correct issue to reference is https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/2

But that was apparently resolved with latest code pushed out with Creators Update.

Thoughts?

Wasn't sure which branch to send PR against, so using master for now. I can always re-submit.

data.title: Please add search ability for Pull Requests
data.body:
- 1.10.0
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.15063]

Steps to Reproduce:
Bring up Pull Requests page
See that you can search by "Created By" and "Assigned to"
There is no other way to search that I have found.

Our team creates literally 100's of PRs each day. Sometimes the PR number or title is referred to in email or in the WI text, but the PR is closed and it is unknown who created the PR. There is no way to search for the PR.
For example, I have text in a WI that says: "See discussion in GigJam Pull Request: 53828,  Fix widget"
I would very much like the ability to search for the PR with it's number: 53828, just like you can search for a Work Item ID in the Queries page.
I have found a 3rd party utility that gives me this ability, but it requires the administrators to install it. I do not have access.

data.title: Use Chromium's new system-ui font alias
data.body:
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=654679

Fixes #10144.

As @Tyriar [pointed out](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10144#issuecomment-242803110), `sans-serif` didn't work. But Chromium 56 added `system-ui` (similar to `-apple-system` but for all operation systems) in Electron :)

data.title: For changed file, save time not updated in windows Explorer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|bracket-pair-colorizer|CoenraadS|0.10.3|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.0.1|
|angular2-inline|natewallace|0.0.17|
|typescript-hero|rbbit|0.12.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make a change in a program file within VSCode
2. Close VSCode
3. Using a low-level file display program, verify that the file was indeed changed. 
4. Check the file save time for the file.  It is not updated.

Why this matters:

It is often useful to see at a glance in Windows Explorer which files changed.  The behavior of VSCode breaks the convention of changes in a file being reflected in the file date listing in Windows Explorer.

data.title: Multiple editors open for the same file
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and use a problem matcher that uses captures absolute file names instead of relative file names
1. Open a file in project and edit the file to have a compilation error
2. Compile your project, error should show up as a problem
3. View the output pane showing the absolute path to your file
4. Hold down `Ctrl` and left click on the file name
5. Observe that the file is opened in another editor, and now you have 2 editors with the same file open

data.title: Pasting R code into the integrated terminal is broken
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code GUI, open up the integrated terminal.
2. Start an R session in the integrated terminal by tying `R`.
3. Paste the following text into the integrated terminal

```
idx.training <- sample(seq(1:nrow(df)), 0.6 * nrow(df))
df.train  <- df[idx.training,]
df.test   <- df[-idx.training,]
df.tr <- df.train[,c("home","vst","year","day_of_week","day_night","attendance","lagged_att","fci","vst_pop", "home_pop", "vst_income","home_income","prcp_matched","aptmp_matched","wind_matched","cloud_matched","home_avg_runs_5","vst_avg_runs_5")]
df.te <- df.test[,c("home","vst","year","day_of_week","day_night","attendance","lagged_att","fci","vst_pop", "home_pop", "vst_income","home_income","prcp_matched","aptmp_matched","wind_matched","cloud_matched","home_avg_runs_5","vst_avg_runs_5")]

df.model.lm <- lm(attendance ~ year+day_of_week+day_night+attendance+lagged_att+vst_pop+home_pop+vst_income+home_income+prcp_matched+aptmp_matched+wind_matched+cloud_matched+home_avg_runs_5+vst_avg_runs_5+home+vst,df.tr)
df.predict.lm <-  predict(df.model.lm,df.te)
df.predict.lm.rmse <- sqrt(mean((df.predict.lm - df.te$attendance)^2,na.rm=TRUE))
print(paste("Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE):", df.predict.lm.rmse))
pdf('lm_model.pdf',8,8)
plot(df.predict.lm, df.te$attendance, main="Linear Regression Preditions vs. Actual",
     xlab="Predicted", ylab="Actual")
abline(0, 1, lty=2)
legend("topleft", c("Data", "Perfect Model"), pch=c(1, NA), lty=c(NA, 2))
dev.off()
```

An excerpt of the output is 

```
> print(paste("Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE):", df.predict.lm.print(paste("Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE):", df.predteprint(past
e("Root Mean Squareression Preditions vs. Actual",
+      xlab="Predicted", ylab="Actual")
+ abline(0, 1, lty=2)
Error: unexpected symbol in:
"     xlab="Predicted", ylab="Actual")
abline"
> legend("topleft", c("Data", "Perfect Model"), pch=c(1, NA), lty=c(NA, 2))
Error in strwidth(legend, units = "user", cex = cex, font = text.font) :
  plot.new has not been called yet
> dev.off()
null device
          1
```

Now, if I paste it into ``Terminal.app`` with an R session launched inside it, the error ``Error: unexpected symbol in`` does not occur. **Notice that in the example I did not import the dataset so there is a bunch of errors**, but that shouldn't matter. If I load the correct dataset, ``Terminal.app`` will execute my R code successfully in an interactive R session while the integrated fails at the error ``Error: unexpected symbol in``. I did not change any settings in VS Code.

data.title: Problems listed in the problem pane do not show error code
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

There does not appear to be any way to show the error code for problems listed in the PROBLEMS output pane. In order to get the error code, one must go back and search through the OUTPUT pane. Many C/C++ compilers will provide an error code for any errors/warnings encounters, which can then be disabled via a compile flag or `#pragma` which references the error number. So it would be very helpful if the problems listed in the PROBLEM pane displayed the error code, instead of forcing the user to go back and search through the OUTPUT pane to get the error code.

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a problem matcher that saves the error code
2. Run build
3. View list of problems in the problem output pane
4. Observe that there is no error code displayed for any of the problems

data.title: A rendering bug when typing Arabic after an English word
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Latest and greatest (Both stable:  1.11.2 / Insiders: 1.12.0-insider)
- OS Version: mac sierra

Today I found a very interesting bug. Which is not something that should normally be bothering anyone but maybe it's better to be fixed. I was unaware that my keyboard layout was Persian and I typed:
```
ُ
```
After the `constructor` and look what happens when you actually do that:

![arabic-vaj-probelm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2157285/25494561/3843bbc0-2b8f-11e7-978e-2fd550fae292.gif)

So I guess you can use this to reproduce the bug

```
            constructorٍ ( ) {

            }
```

I believe the problem is with [`U+0610` to `U+061A`](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_script_in_Unicode).

As always thanks you so much for the Code, It's the best goddamn editor ever existed and really changed my workflow to something that every time I run it I feel so grateful.
Wishing you an awesome awesome time.

data.title: window.zoomLevel negatively affects tab size
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|vs-keybindings|ms-vscode|0.1.3|
|sass-indented|robinbentley|1.4.1|
|theme-bracketslight|ullissescastro|1.0.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Increase the window zoom level to level 3 (Ctrl+=)
2. Navigate to the Extensions View
3. Click any extension installed, or any displayed from a search result.
4. The first tab (Details) does not flex to fill the available horizontal  or vertical space, making the document narrow and requiring more vertical scrolling.
5. This manifests itself in various tabs throughout VS Code.

To double check that the current zoom level, navigate to the settings and the user settings section.

I noticed this in another recent commit.

Should be "faded" instead of "striked-through" for this field.

data.title: Add setting to allow the tab bar to be shown only if there is more than one tab
data.body:
I would find it useful to be able to suppress the tab bar if only one file is open in a given workspace, in order to reduce clutter and to save vertical screen space.

To support this, the workbench.editor.showTabs setting could be generalised to have values ('always', 'withMoreThanOneTab' or 'never', perhaps) or another setting could be added alongside it.

This is a setting I've seen in some other editors; for example the SciTE editor (a thin wrapper around Scintilla) supports this with its 'tabbar.hide.one' setting.

data.title: HTML Wrap attributes doesn't work
data.body: On HTML (in our case, Angular Component html), auto formatter (`ALT + SHIFT + F` on windows) does not wrap attributes to new line even if the param is set to `force` in settings. - VSCode Version: 1.11.2 - OS Version: Win 10 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set `"html.format.wrapAttributes": "force"` in user settings 2. Create a file with this HTML: ```html ``` It doesn't wrap attributes. I expected to have: ```html ``` Worst, if HTML has already wrapped attributes, it replace them on the same line. **Is the setting still used?**

data.title: Git Extension: Choose branches and get a list of changed files
data.body:
Hi,

Today in the Git extension you get a list of files that has changed since the last commit, this is a feature that is really appreciated!

I think it would be neat if this could be extended so that the user can choose two branches and get a list of files that has changed between them. When you click on a file you get the compare window just as today.

In other words there are two drop-down lists and when 'master' and 'my_work_branch' are chosen I get a list of files that has changed between these branches. 
'my_work_branch' and 'Not Committed Files' gives a list of files exactly as today and could be the default selection of the two drop-down lists.

Perhaps the selections could be extended even more so that you can select between commits in one branch, i.e. 'my_work_branch/1' and 'my_work_branch/5' gives a list of files that has changed between these commits. 

For my own preference I believe it would be enough to just compare between the last version of each branch and files that has been changed but not committed. I try to keep changes in my work branch to a minimum and then it would be great to see ALL the changes I have done against the master branch.

With this feature it would be quite easy to compare the difference between branches and also to copy desired functionality (code) between branches through the compare window.

data.title: Problems with symlinks and file events

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- OS Version: reproduced under Windows & Mac

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create new workspace
2. outside the workspace create an empty tasks.json file
3. inside the workspace create a .vscode folder
4. create a sym link .vscode\tasks.json to the file created in step 2
5. open VS Code and add the following content to the tasks.json file
```
{
	"version": "0.1.0",
	"command": "dir",
	"isShellCommand": true
}
```
6. F1 > Run task. Observe: no tasks are detected. 
7. Reload workspace
8. Observe: tasks are now detected.

The reason for this is that the change to tasks.json in step 5. doesn't trigger a file event on that file. It triggers an event on the original file hence we don't reread the config and sent an event.

But unless we have support from the OS for this I am not sure how to best fix this.
